message.content:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: 
// Equivalent of String.Format
String formattedString = String.format("Hello, %s!", "World");

// Equivalent of String.Join
List<String> list = Arrays.asList("Hello", "World");
String joinedString = String.join(" ", list);

// Using Iterator.next
Iterator<String> iterator = list.iterator();
while (iterator.hasNext()) {
    System.out.println(iterator.next());
}
<<<explanation>>>: In Java, the equivalent of C#'s String.Format() is String.format(). It allows you to create a formatted string using placeholders. The equivalent of String.Join() is String.join(). It concatenates the elements of an array or collection with a specified delimiter. The Iterator.next() method is used to get the next element in a collection. It's not directly related to string formatting or joining, but it's a common method used when working with collections in Java.
